title: A taste for privacy
subtitle: When do people give up their privacy?

intro.value: Spoiler: Privacy depends on who you are and and context.
Privacy depends on who you are and context. Your willingness to share data varies dramatically across different institutions and relationships.
In this survey, we asked people about their relative trust in different institutions.
Lets start with a simple question; how do young people these days set up their privacy settings on social media?
We can see that most college students today set their accounts to private, followed by mixed, then public. Overall, **we find that more social media use leads to less private settings**.
This gives us a first glimpse, but: is social media a good proxy for their broader “taste for privacy”?

steps.value: To investigate that question, we asked a series of questions about how comfortable are each respondent with sharing personally identifiable (PII) data with a a number of institution, broadly understood. What if the comfort of sharing data with a particular institution is about the distance from self, which we call _privacy construal_.

For instance, here's the circle of trust for all our respondents of how sharing PII with social media platforms. We also are going to keep a ranked bar chart to help us interpret the relative ranking of all institutions of interest.

conclusion.value: So privacy do depends on who you are and and context.
